Problem:
Consider a system governed by the Laplace transform of a function \\( g(t) \\), denoted as \\( G(s) = \\mathcal{L}\\{g(t)\\}(s) \\). We investigate how the application of a convolution transformation defined by kernel \\( h(t) \\), with its Laplace transform \\( H(s) \\), affects the system.

If an intervention by altering the kernel to a new kernel \\( j(t) \\) with Laplace transform \\( J(s) \\) is applied at a time \\( t_1 \\), will the Laplace transform of the resultant function \\( \\mathcal{L}\\{(g \\ast j)(t)\\}(s) \\) at any \\( s \\) depend only on \\( J(s) \\) and not on the previous kernel \\( H(s) \\)?
Explanation: The intervention modifies the convolution kernel from \\( h(t) \\) to \\( j(t) \\). Since the system evolves under \\( g(t) \\) convoluted with the new kernel post-intervention, the resultant Laplace transform reflects \\( G(s)J(s) \\), independent of the previous \\( H(s) \\). The causal effect is reset with the intervention.
